dict.string: Configures Firefox settings. Firefox 78 is the last major release with support for macOS versions 10.9, 10.10 and 10.11.
A unique identifier for the payload, dot-delimited. Usually root PayloadIdentifier+subidentifier.
The type of the payload, a reverse dns string.
The version of the whole configuration profile.
This value describes the issuing organization of the profile, as displayed to the user.

macOS defaults takes precedence over JSON policies (an alternative method to manage Firefox preferences). This preference must be set to true in macOS defaults in order to manage Firefox preferences through macOS defaults (configuration profile, plist, etc.). Once this value is set to true, JSON policies set through a policies.json config file (e.g. /Applications/Firefox.app/Contents/Resources/distribution/policies.json) are disabled even if no other policies are set in macOS defaults (this configuration profile).

macOS defaults takes precedence over JSON policies (an alternative method to manage Firefox preferences). This preference must be set to true in macOS defaults in order to manage Firefox preferences through macOS defaults (configuration profile, plist, etc.). Once this value is set to true, JSON policies set through a policies.json config file (e.g. /Applications/Firefox.app/Contents/Resources/distribution/policies.json) are disabled even if no other policies are set in macOS defaults (this configuration profile).
Enable or disable automatic application update.

Enable or disable automatic application update.
If set to true, application updates are installed without user approval.
If set to false, application updates are downloaded but the user can choose when to install the update.
If you have disabled updates via DisableAppUpdate, this policy has no effect.

array.string: Check for updates, user chooses when to install

dict.string: Change the URL for application update.

This preference is for changing the URL used for application update. E.g. https://www.example.com/update.xml
For more information on setting up your own update server: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Mozilla/Setting_up_an_update_server
For more information on setting up your own update server: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Mozilla/Setting_up_an_update_server
Configure sites that support integrated authentication.
This preference is for configuring sites that support integrated authentication. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication for more information.

If this preference is enabled, the specified websites are permitted to engage in SPNEGO authentication with the browser. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, no websites are permitted to engage in SPNEGO authentication with the browser.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, the specified websites are permitted to engage in SPNEGO authentication with the browser. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, no websites are permitted to engage in SPNEGO authentication with the browser.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication.

If this preference is enabled, the browser may delegate user authorization to the server for the specified websites. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, the browser will not delegate user authorization to the server for any websites.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication

Optional. If this preference is enabled, the browser may delegate user authorization to the server for the specified websites. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, the browser will not delegate user authorization to the server for any websites.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication

If this preference is enabled, the specified websites are trusted to use NTLM authentification. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this policy is disabled or not configured, no websites are trusted to use NTLM authentification.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, the specified websites are trusted to use NTLM authentification. Entries in the list are formatted as mydomain.com or https://myotherdomain.com.
If this policy is disabled or not configured, no websites are trusted to use NTLM authentification.
For more information, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Integrated_authentication.

If this preference is enabled, you can always allow SPNEGO or NTLM on non FQDNs (fully qualified domain names). If this preference is disabled or not configured, NTLM and SPNEGO are not enabled on non FQDNs.

If this preference is enabled, you can always allow SPNEGO or NTLM on non FQDNs (fully qualified domain names). If this preference is disabled or not configured, NTLM and SPNEGO are not enabled on non FQDNs.

If this preference is enabled, you can always allow SPNEGO or NTLM on non FQDNs (fully qualified domain names). If this preference is disabled or not configured, NTLM and SPNEGO are not enabled on non FQDNs.

If this preference is enabled, you can always allow SPNEGO or NTLM on non FQDNs (fully qualified domain names). If this preference is disabled or not configured, NTLM and SPNEGO are not enabled on non FQDNs.
Enables integrated authentication in prviate browsing
Block access to the Add-ons Manager (about:addons).
This preference removes access to about:addons.
This preference removes access to about:config.
This preference removes access to about:profiles.
This preference removes access to about:support.
Add bookmarks in either the bookmarks toolbar or menu.

Add bookmarks in either the bookmarks toolbar or menu. Only Title and URL are required. If Placement is not specified, the bookmark will be placed on the toolbar. If Folder is specified, it is automatically created and bookmarks with the same folder name are grouped together.
Full URL to be bookmarked (e.g. https://www.example.org/)
Full URL to be bookmarked (e.g. https://www.example.org/)
Place bookmark in either the Bookmark menu or Bookmark Toolbar.
Place bookmark in either the Bookmark menu or Bookmark Toolbar.
URL to icon file to display on bookmark (e.g. https://www.example.org/favicon.ico)
URL to icon file to display on bookmark (e.g. https://www.example.org/favicon.ico)
Folder to place bookmark in. If a folder is specified, it is automatically created and bookmarks with the same folder name are grouped together. You cannot nest folders.
Folder to place bookmark in. If a folder is specified, it is automatically created and bookmarks with the same folder name are grouped together. You cannot nest folders.
You can use ${home} for the native home directory.
This preference turns off application updates.
Disable the built in PDF viewer. PDF files are downloaded and sent externally.
This preference disables the built in PDF viewer. PDF files are downloaded and sent externally.
This setting can also be managed with the PDFjs preference, which has more granular options. Use one or the other.
Disable or configure PDF.js, the built-in PDF viewer.
This builds on the older DisableBuiltinPDFViewer preference. Use one or the other.
If Enabled is set to false, the built-in PDF viewer is disabled.
If EnablePermissions is set to true, the built-in PDF viewer will honor document permissions like preventing the copying of text.
Remove access to all developer tools.
This preference removes access to all developer tools.
Disable the menus for reporting sites (Submit Feedback, Report Deceptive Site).
This preference disables the menus for reporting sites (Submit Feedback, Report Deceptive Site).
This preference removes access to Firefox Screenshots.
Remove the master password functionality. If this preference is set to true, the master password functionality is removed.

If this value is true, it works the same as if PrimaryPassword was false and removes the primary password functionality. If both DisableMasterPasswordCreation and PrimaryPassword are used, DisableMasterPasswordCreation takes precedent.
Require or prevent using a primary (formerly master) password. If this value is true, a primary password is required.

If this value is false, it works the same as if DisableMasterPasswordCreation was true and removes the primary password functionality. If both DisableMasterPasswordCreation and PrimaryPassword are used, DisableMasterPasswordCreation takes precedent.
Remove Pocket in the Firefox UI.
This does not remove it from the new tab page.
This preference removes access to private browsing.
Disables the "Import data from another browser" option in the bookmarks window.
This preference disables the "Import data from another browser" option in the bookmarks window.
Disable the Refresh Firefox button on about:support and support.mozilla.org, as well as the prompt that displays offering to refresh Firefox when you haven't used it in a while.
This preference disables the Refresh Firefox button on about:support and support.mozilla.org.
Disable safe mode within the browser.
This preference removes the "Set As Desktop Background..." menu item when right clicking on an image.
This preference removes the "Set As Desktop Background..." menu item when right clicking on an image.
Set the initial state of the menubar. A user can still hide it and it will stay hidden.
Prevent system add-ons from being installed or update.
This preference prevents system add-ons from being updated or installed.
Set the initial state of the bookmarks toolbar. A user can still hide it and it will stay hidden.
This preference turns on the bookmarks toolbar by default. A user can still turn it off, and it will stay off.
Don't check if Firefox is the default browser at startup.
This preference stops Firefox from checking if it is the default browser at startup.
Set and lock the download directory.
Set and lock the download directory.
You can use ${home} for the native home directory.

Control the installation, uninstallation and locking of extensions. Locked extensions cannot be disabled or uninstalled. For Install, you specify a list of URLs or paths. For Uninstall and Locked, you specify extension IDs.

This preference controls the installation, uninstallation and locking of extensions. Locked extensions cannot be disabled or uninstalled. For Install, you specify a list of URLs or paths. For Uninstall and Locked, you specify extension IDs. For more on determining extension IDs: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Determine_extension_ID
For more on determining extension IDs: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Determine_extension_ID
A list of URLs or native paths for extensions to be installed.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, you can specify a list of extension URLs or paths that will be installed when Firefox is started. Anytime this list is changed, the extensions will be reinstalled. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no extensions are installed. Example of valid entries are: "https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/downloads/somefile.xpi" or "//path/to/xpi"
A list of extension IDs that should be uninstalled if found.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, you can specify a list of extension IDs that will be uninstalled. Anytime this list is changed, the extensions will be uninstalled. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no extensions are uninstalled.
A list of extension IDs that the user cannot disable or uninstall.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, you can specify a list of extension IDs that the user will be unable to uninstall or disable. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no extensions are locked
Manage all aspects of extensions. A default configuration can be set for the special ID "*", which will apply to all extensions that don't have a custom configuration set in this policy.

Manage all aspects of extensions. This policy is based heavily on the Chrome policy of the same name.
This policy maps an extension ID to its configuration. With an extension ID, the configuration will be applied to the specified extension only. A default configuration can be set for the special ID "*", which will apply to all extensions that don't have a custom configuration set in this policy.
To obtain an extension ID, install the extension and go to about:support. You will see the ID in the Extensions section. I've also created an extension that makes it easy to find the ID of extensions on AMO. You can download it here (https://github.com/mkaply/queryamoid/releases/tag/v0.1).
The configuration for each extension is another dictionary that can contain the fields documented below.
This policy is based heavily on the Chrome policy of the same name.
Maps to a string indicating the installation mode for the extension.

Maps to a string indicating where Firefox can download a force_installed or normal_installed extension. If installing from the addons.mozilla.org, use the following URL (substituting SHORT_NAME from the URL on AMO), https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/downloads/latest/SHORT_NAME/latest.xpi. If installing from the local file system, use a file:/// URL. Languages packs are available from https://releases.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/releases/VERSION/PLATFORM/xpi/LANGUAGE.xpi.
Each item in this list is an extension-style match pattern.

Each item in this list is an extension-style match pattern. Users will be able to easily install items from any URL that matches an item in this list. Both the location of the *.xpi file and the page where the download is started from (i.e. the referrer) must be allowed by these patterns. This setting can be used only for the default configuration.
This setting allowlists the allowed types of extension/apps that can be installed in Firefox.

This setting whitelists the allowed types of extension/apps that can be installed in Firefox. The value is a list of strings, each of which should be one of the following: "extension", "theme", "dictionary", "langpack" This setting can be used only for the default configuration.
This maps to a string specifying the error message to display to users if they're blocked from installing an extension.

This maps to a string specifying the error message to display to users if they're blocked from installing an extension. This setting allows you to append text to the generic error message displayed when the extension is blocked. This could be be used to direct users to your help desk, explain why a particular extension is blocked, or something else.
An array of domains on which content scripts can't be run.
This setting can be used only for the default configuration.
Indicates whether or not to disable automatic updates for an individual extension.
Enable or disable Encrypted Media Extensions and optionally lock it.
If Enabled is set to false, encrypted media extensions (like Widevine) are not downloaded by Firefox unless the user consents to installing them.
If Locked is set to true and Enabled is set to false, Firefox will not download encrypted media extensions (like Widevine) or ask the user to install them.
This preference disables hardware acceleration by locking the preference layers.acceleration.disabled to true.
Configure the default homepage and how Firefox starts.
This preference sets the default homepage value and the default start page. It can also be used to lock the homepage or add additional homepages.
Optional. Set the default home page.
Optional. This preference sets what displays when Firefox starts. It can be the homepage, the previous session, or a blank page.
Optional. This preference sets what displays when Firefox starts. It can be the homepage, the previous session, or a blank page.

With Firefox 78, an additional option was added for Startpage, homepage-locked. This allows for locking the homepage, but still allowing the user to choose whether or not they want to restore their session.
If true, prevents the user from changing homepage preferences.
Optional. If this is true, Homepage preferences cannot be changed.
Show the home button on the toolbar. Future versions of Firefox will not show the home button by default.
Enable linking to local files by origin
Enable linking to local files by origin.
Enable or disable the New Tab page.
Enable or disable the New Tab page.
Disable the creation of default bookmarks.

This preference prevents the default bookmarks or the Smart Bookmarks (Most Visited, Recent Tags) from being created. Note: this preference is only effective if used before the first run of the profile.
This policy is only effective if the user profile has not been created yet.
Override the first run page. If the value is blank, no first run page is displayed. Starting with Firefox 83, Firefox ESR 78.5, you can also specify multiple URLS separated by a vertical bar (|).
This preference allows you to override the first run page. If you leave the URL blank, the first run page will not be displayed. E.g. https://www.example.com
Override the upgrade page. If the value is blank, no upgrade page is displayed.
This preference allows you to override the upgrade page. If you leave the URL blank, the upgrade page will not be displayed.
Ask where to save each file before downloading.
Ask where to save each file before downloading.
Set the the list of requested locales for the application in order of preference. It will cause the corresponding language pack to become active.
This preference sets the list of requested locales for the application in order of preference. It will cause the corresponding language pack to become active.
For Firefox 68, this can now be a string so that you can specify an empty value.
Clear data on shutdown. Choose from Cache, Cookies, Download History, Form & Search History, Browsing History, Active Logins, Site Preferences and Offline Website Data.
Clear data on shutdown. Choose from Cache, Cookies, Download History, Form & Search History, Browsing History, Active Logins, Site Preferences and Offline Website Data.

Previously, these values were always locked. Starting with Firefox 74 and Firefox ESR 68.6, you can use the 'Locked' option to either keep the values unlocked (set it to false), or lock only the values you set (set it to true). If you want the old behavior of locking everything, do not set Locked at all.
Set whether or not search bar is displayed.
This preference can be used to determine if the search bar is separate or combined with the URL bar.
Set whether or not search bar is displayed.
This policy is only available on the ESR.
Set the default search engine. This policy is only available on the ESR.
Prevent installing search engines from webpages. This policy is only available on the ESR.
Hide built-in search engines. This policy is only available on the ESR.
Add new search engines. This policy is only available on the ESR.
You can only include up to 5 search engines and Name & URL are required.
URL for the icon to use
keyword to use for the engine
POST data as name value pairs separated by '&'
Search suggestions URL with {searchTerms} to substitute for the search term.

Configure default application handlers. This policy is based on the internal format of handlers.json. You can configure handlers based on a mime type (mimeTypes), a file's extension (extensions), or a protocol (schemes).
Specify MIME types. More info here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types
Can be either saveToDisk, useHelperApp, useSystemDefault.
If true, the user is asked if what they want to do with the file. If false, the action is taken without user intervention.
Can be either saveToDisk, useHelperApp, useSystemDefault.
If true, the user is asked if what they want to do with the file. If false, the action is taken without user intervention.
An array of handlers with the first one being the default. If you don't want to have a default handler, use an empty object for the first handler. Choose between path or uriTemplate.
The display name of the handler (might not be used).
The native path to the executable to be used.
A url to a web based application handler. The URL must be https and contain a %s to be used for substitution.
The URL must be https and contain a %s to be used for substitution.
Can be either saveToDisk, useHelperApp, useSystemDefault.
If true, the user is asked if what they want to do with the file. If false, the action is taken without user intervention.
An array of handlers with the first one being the default. If you don't want to have a default handler, use an empty object for the first handler. Choose between path or uriTemplate.
The display name of the handler (might not be used).
The native path to the executable to be used.
A url to a web based application handler. The URL must be https and contain a %s to be used for substitution.
The URL must be https and contain a %s to be used for substitution.

Disable specific cryptographic ciphers. This policy was updated in Firefox 78 to allow enabling ciphers as well. Setting the value to true disables the cipher, setting the value to false enables the cipher. Previously setting the value to true or false disabled the cipher.
This preference configures DNS over HTTPS.
URL to an alternative DNS over HTTPS provider.
Required. URL to an alternative DNS over HTTPS provider.
If this is true, DNS over HTTPS preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this is true, DNS over HTTPS preferences cannot be changed.
List of excluded domains from DNS over HTTPS.
Configure proxy settings. These settings correspond to the connection settings in Firefox preferences. To specify ports, append them to the hostnames with a colon (:).

This preference allows you to specify proxy settings. These settings correspond to the connection settings in Firefox preferences. To specify ports, append them to the hostnames with a colon (:). If Locked is set to true, the values cannot be changed by the user.
If Locked is set to true, the values cannot be changed by the user.
If this preference is enabled, you will be setting the proxy mode.
Required. If this preference is enabled, you will be setting the proxy mode.
If this preference is enabled, Proxy preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, Proxy preferences cannot be changed.
If this preference is enabled, do not prompt for authentication if password is saved.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, do not prompt for authentication if password is saved.
If this preference is enabled, you will use Proxy DNS when using SOCKS v5.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, you will use Proxy DNS when using SOCKS v5.
If this preference is enabled, use the HTTP proxy server for all protocols.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, use the HTTP proxy server for all protocols.
This policy allows you to set the minimum TLS version.
This policy allows you to set the maximum TLS version.
Enable or disable network prediction (DNS prefetching).
This policy enables or disables network prediction (DNS prefetching) by setting and locking the preferences network.dns.disablePrefetch and network.dns.disablePrefetchFromHTTPS.
This preference controls various settings related to cookies.
A list of origins (not domains) where cookies are always allowed.
You must include http or https.
A list of origins (not domains) where cookies are only allowed for the current session.
You must include http or https.
A list of origins (not domains) where cookies are always blocked.
You must include http or https.
This sets the default value for "Accept cookies from websites".
Optional. This sets the default value for "Accept cookies from websites".
This sets the default value for "Accept third-party cookies".
Optional. This sets the default value for "Accept third-party cookies".
Optional. This determines when cookies expire.
If this is true, cookies preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this is true, cookies preferences cannot be changed.
Turn off saving information on web forms and the search bar.
This preference turns off the browser.formfill.enable preferences.
Do not allow passwords to be shown in saved logins
Prevent the upload of telemetry data.

This preference prevents the upload of telemetry data. Mozilla recommends that you do not disable telemetry. Information collected through telemetry helps Mozilla build a better product for businesses like yours.
Mozilla recommends that you do not disable telemetry. Information collected through telemetry helps build a better product for businesses like yours.

Configure tracking protection. If this policy is not configured, tracking protection is not enabled by default in the browser, but it is enabled by default in private browsing and the user can change it.

This preference affects tracking protection. If this preference is not configured, tracking protection is not enabled by default in the browser, but it is enabled by default in private browsing and the user can change it.

If Value is set to false, tracking protection is disabled and locked in both the regular browser and private browsing. If Value is set to true, tracking protection is enabled by default in both the regular browser and private browsing.

Optional. If Value is set to false, tracking protection is disabled and locked in both the regular browser and private browsing. If Value is set to true, tracking protection is enabled by default in both the regular browser and private browsing.
If this is true, Tracking Protection preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this is true, Tracking Protection preferences cannot be changed.
If Cryptomining is set to true, cryptomining scripts on websites are blocked.
If Cryptomining is set to true, cryptomining scripts on websites are blocked.
If Fingerprinting is set to true, fingerprinting scripts on websites are blocked.
If Fingerprinting is set to true, fingerprinting scripts on websites are blocked.
Configure the default Flash plugin policy as well as origins for which Flash is allowed.
This preference sets the behavior of Flash on the specified domains as well as the default behavior.

If this preference is enabled, sites on the allow list do not override Flash being completely disabled. Flash is activated by default for the domains indicated unless Flash is completely disabled. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), Flash is allowed for all subdomains as well.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites on the allow list do not override Flash being completely disabled. Flash is activated by default for the domains indicated unless Flash is completely disabled. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), Flash is allowed for all subdomains as well.
If this preference is enabled, Flash is blocked for the domains indicated. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), Flash is blocked from all subdomains as well.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, Flash is blocked for the domains indicated. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), Flash is blocked from all subdomains as well.
If this is true, Flash preferences cannot be changed. If this is false, Flash is never activated on websites even if they are in the specified in the Allow list.
Optional. If this is true, Flash preferences cannot be changed. If this is false, Flash is never activated on websites even if they are in the specified in the Allow list.
If this is true, Flash preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this is true, Flash preferences cannot be changed.
Configure the default extension install policy as well as origins for extension installs are allowed.
This preference sets domains that can install extensions as well as the default behavior. If default behavior value is set to false, add-ons cannot be installed by the user.
This policy does not override turning off all extension installs.

If this preference is enabled, add-ons are always allowed for the domains indicated unless add-on install is disabled. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), add-ons are allowed for all subdomains as well.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, add-ons are always allowed for the domains indicated unless add-on install is disabled. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), add-ons are allowed for all subdomains as well.
If this is set to false, add-ons cannot be installed by the user.
Optional. If this is set to false, add-ons cannot be installed by the user.
Control whether or not Firefox offers to save passwords.
This preference sets the signon.rememberSignons preference. It determines whether or not Firefox offers to save passwords. It can either be enabled or disabled.
Sets the default value of signon.rememberSignons without locking it.
Remove access to the password manager via preferences and blocks about:logins on Firefox 70.
Set permissions associated with camera, microphone, location, notifications, and autoplay.
This preference allows you to change the permissions associated with camera, microphone, location, notifications, and autoplay.
This preference allows you to change the camera permissions.
If this preference is enabled, access to the camera is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default camera preference is followed.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to the camera is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default camera preference is followed.
If this preference is enabled, access to the camera is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the camera is not blocked by default.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to the camera is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the camera is not blocked by default.

If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access the camera. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the camera.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access the camera. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the camera.
If this preference is enabled, camera preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their camera preferences.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, camera preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their camera preferences.
This preference allows you to change the microphone permissions.
If this preference is enabled, access to the microphone is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default microphone preference is followed.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to the microphone is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default microphone preference is followed.
If this preference is enabled, access to the microphone is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the microphone is not blocked by default.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to the microphone is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the microphone is not blocked by default.

If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access the microphone. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the microphone.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access the microphone. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the microphone.
If this preference is enabled, microphone preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their microphone preferences.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, microphone preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their microphone preferences.
This preference allows you to change the location permissions.
If this preference is enabled, access to location is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default location preference is followed.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to location is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default location preference is followed.
If this preference is enabled, access to location is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to location is not blocked by default.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to location is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to location is not blocked by default.

If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access location. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the location.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access location. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access the location.
If this preference is enabled, location preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their location preferences.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, location preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their location preferences.
This preference allows you to change the notifications permissions.
If this preference is enabled, notifications can always be sent for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default nofication preference is followed.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, notifications can always be sent for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default nofication preference is followed.
If this preference is enabled, notifications are always blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, notifications are not blocked by default.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, notifications are always blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, notifications are not blocked by default.

If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to send notifications. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to send notifications.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to send notifications. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to send notifications.
If this preference is enabled, notification preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their notification preferences.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, location preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their location preferences.
This preference allows you to change the autoplay permissions.
If this preference is enabled, autoplay can always be enabled for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default autoplay preference is followed.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, autoplay can always be enabled for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default autoplay preference is followed.
If this preference is enabled, autoplay are always blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, autoplay is not blocked by default.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, autoplay are always blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, autoplay is not blocked by default.
If this preference is enabled, autoplay preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their autoplay preferences.
Optional. If this preference is enabled, autoplay preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their autoplay preferences.
This preference allows you to change the virtual reality permissions.

If this preference is enabled, access to virtual reality is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default virtual reality preference is followed.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to the virtual reality is always allowed for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the default virtual reality preference is followed.

If this preference is enabled, access to virtual reality is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the virtual reality is not blocked by default.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, access to virtual reality is blocked for the domains indicated. If this preference is disabled or not configured, access to the virtual reality is not blocked by default.

If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access virtual reality. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access virtual reality.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, sites that are not in the Allow preference will not be allowed to ask permission to access virtual reality. If this preference is disabled or not configured, any site that is not in the Block preference can ask permission to access virtual reality.
If this preference is enabled, virtual reality preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their virtual reality preferences.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, virtual reality preferences cannot be changed by the user. If this preference is disabled or not configured, the user can change their virtual reality preferences.
Configure the default pop-up window policy as well as origins for which pop-up windows are allowed.
This preference sets domains for which pop-up windows are allowed. It also sets the default pop-up preference.
Specify the domains for which pop-up windows are always allowed. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), pop-up windows are allowed for all subdomains as well.
Optional. Specify the domains for which pop-up windows are always allowed. If a top level domain is specified (http://example.org), pop-up windows are allowed for all subdomains as well.
If this is false, pop-up windows are allowed by default.
Optional. If this is false, pop-up windows are allowed by default.
If this is true, pop-up blocking preferences cannot be changed.
Optional. If this is true, pop-up blocking preferences cannot be changed.
Trust certificates that have been added to the operating system certificate store by a user or administrator in the macOS Keychain.

This preference can be used to install certificates or to read (import) certificates from the system certificate store on macOS (keychain). Certificates can be located in the following locations: /Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates ~/Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates
In Firefox 65, you can specify a fully qualified path.

Certificates can be located in the following locations: /Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates ~/Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates See https://support.mozilla.org/kb/setting-certificate-authorities-firefox for more detail.
If this preference is enabled, Firefox will read certificates from the macOS keychain. If this preference is disabled or not configured, Firefox will not read certificates from the macOS keychain.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, Firefox will read certificates from the macOS keychain. If this preference is disabled or not configured, Firefox will not read certificates from the macOS keychain.

If this preference is enabled, Firefox will install the listed certificates. It will look in /Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates and ~/Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, Firefox will not install additional certificates.
Starting in Firefox 65, you can specify a fully qualified path (e.g. /Library/Company/cer1.der). If Firefox does not find something at your fully qualified path, it will search the default directories.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, Firefox will install the listed certificates. It will look in /Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates and ~/Library/Application Support/Mozilla/Certificates.
If this preference is disabled or not configured, Firefox will not install additional certificates.
Starting in Firefox 65, you can specify a fully qualified path (e.g. /Library/Company/cer1.der). If Firefox does not find something at your fully qualified path, it will search the default directories.
Prevent the user from bypassing security in certain cases.
This preference prevents the user from bypassing security in certain cases.

Prevents adding an exception when an invalid certificate is shown. If this preference is enabled, the "Add Exception" button is not available when a certificate is invalid. This prevents the user from overriding the certificate error. If this preference is disabled or not configured, certificate errors can be overridden.

Optional. Prevents adding an exception when an invalid certificate is shown. If this preference is enabled, the "Add Exception" button is not available when a certificate is invalid. This prevents the user from overriding the certificate error. If this preference is disabled or not configured, certificate errors can be overridden.

Prevents selecting "ignore the risk" and visiting a harmful site anyway. If this preference is enabled, a user cannot bypass the warning and visit a harmful site. If this preference is disabled or not configured, a user can choose to visit a harmful site.

Optional. Prevents selecting "ignore the risk" and visiting a harmful site anyway. If this preference is enabled, a user cannot bypass the warning and visit a harmful site. If this preference is disabled or not configured, a user can choose to visit a harmful site.
This preference allows you to add PKCS #11 Modules
Prevent installing search engines from webpages.

Prevent installing search engines from webpages.
WhatsNew Remove the "What's New" icon and menuitem. (Firefox 75 only)
ExtensionRecommendations Don't recommend extensions.
FeatureRecommendations Don't recommend browser features.
UrlbarInterventions Don't offer Firefox specific suggestions in the URL bar. (Firefox 75 only)
If enabled, remove the "What's New" icon and menuitem.
If enabled, don't recommend browser features.
If enabled, don't show onboarding messages on the new tab page.
If enabled, don't offer Firefox specific suggestions in the URL bar.

Block websites from being visited. The parameters take an array of Match Patterns, as documented in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Match_patterns. http/https addresses are supported as well as local file:// URLs. The arrays are limited to 1000 entries each.

This preference blocks websites from being visited. The parameters take an array of Match Patterns, as documented in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Match_patterns. Only http/https addresses are supported at the moment. The arrays are limited to 1000 entries each. You cannot have entries in Exceptions without entries in Block.

If this preference is enabled, you can specify match patterns that indicate sites to be blocked. The match patterns are documented at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Match_patterns. Only http/https addresses are supported at the moment. There is a 1000 entry limit. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no websites are blocked.

Required. If this preference is enabled, you can specify match patterns that indicate sites to be blocked. The match patterns are documented at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Match_patterns. Only http/https addresses are supported at the moment. There is a 1000 entry limit. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no websites are blocked.
If you want to block all URLs, you can use <all_urls>

If this preference is enabled, and the website filter is enabled, you can specify match patterns for sites you do not want to block. The match patterns are documented at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Match_patterns. Only http/https addresses are supported at the moment. There is a 1000 entry limit. If this preference is disabled or not configured, there are no exceptions to the website filter.

Optional. If this preference is enabled, you can specify a list of extension IDs that will be uninstalled. Anytime this list is changed, the extensions will be uninstalled. If this preference is disabled or not configured, no extensions are uninstalled.

Comma-separated list of domains allowed to access Google Workspace. This policy is based on the Chrome policy of the same name. If this policy is enabled, users can only access Google Workspace using accounts from the specified domains. If you want to allow Gmail, you can add 'consumer_accounts' to the list.

Comma-separated list of domains allowed to access Google Workspace. This policy is based on the Chrome policy of the same name. If this policy is enabled, users can only access Google Workspace using accounts from the specified domains. If you want to allow Gmail, you can add 'consumer_accounts' to the list.
The protocol to allow for specified URLs.
The protocol to allow for specified URLs.
Enable or disable the detection of captive portals.
This policy enables or disables captive portal support by setting and locking the preference network.captive-portal-service.enabled.
If set to 1, platform accessibility is disabled.
If false, Firefox doesn't automatically install update.
If true, bookmarks are exported on shutdown.
If set, the name of the file where bookmarks are exported and imported.
If true, bookmarks are restored to their defaults.
If false, don't store cache on the hard drive.
If set, changes the location of the disk cache.
Firefox policy documentation indicates this policy doesn't work, but is being worked on.
If true, single words are sent to DNS, not directly to search.
If set, a list of URLs to use as the default top sites on the new tab page.
If true, bookmarks are always imported on startup.
If false, malware protection is not enabled (Not recommended)
If false, phishing protection is not enabled (Not recommended)
If false, updates for search engines are not checked.
If true, a notification isn't shown if startup is slow.
If false, there is no warning when the browser is closed.
If true, tab previews are shown in the Windows taskbar.
If false, bookmarks aren't suggested when typing in the URL bar.
If false, history isn't suggested when typing in the URL bar.
If false, open tabs aren't suggested when typing in the URL bar.
If true, don't show the privacy policy tab on first run.
If false, web page can close windows.
If false, web pages can focus and activate windows.
If true, web pages can't move or resize windows.
If false, web pages can't override context menus.
If false, the extensions blocklist is not used (Not recommended)
If false, the Recommendations tab is not displayed in the Add-ons Manager.
If false, recommendations are not shown on the Extensions tab in the Add-ons Manager.
If false, the geolocation API is disabled.
If set, preferred language for web pages.
If false, Encrypted Media Extensions are not enabled.
If false, the OpenH264 plugin is not downloaded.
If false, the Widevine plugin is not downloaded.
If set, a list of domains for which mDNS hostname obfuscation is disabled.
Prior to v79, this key was media.peerconnection.ice.obfuscate_host_addresses.whitelist.
If true, IPv6 DNS lokoups are disabled.
If true, display the punycode version of internationalized domain names.
If false, history is not enabled.
If false, print settings are not saved between jobs.
If set to "Select Automatically", Firefox automatically chooses the default personal certificate. Other possible option is "Ask Every Time".
If false, mixed active content (HTTP and HTTPS) is not blocked.
If true, client certificates are loaded from the operating system certificate store.
If false, SSL errors cannot be sent to Mozilla.
If false, the TLS 1.3 downgrade check is disabled.
If set, overrides the GTK theme for widgets.
Adds a menuitem to the help menu for specifying support information.
Adds a menuitem to the help menu for specifying support information.
